title: 114_hr1929
content: The "International Conflicts of Concern Act" requires the President to identify countries where foreign terrorist organizations are engaged in armed conflict. The President must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment and update it semi-annually with new information. The report must be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex if needed. SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF COUNTRIES OF CONFLICT CONCERN. The President designates a country as a "Country of Conflict Concern" if allowing foreign terrorist organizations to engage in armed conflict and if it is in the national security interest of the United States to restrict travel and material support to entities involved in armed conflict in that country. The President designates a country as a "Country of Conflict Concern" if foreign terrorist organizations are engaged in armed conflict in that country. Upon designation, the President must submit a report to Congress. The President is authorized to exercise the authorities of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act for countries designated as a Country of Conflict Concern. The Act requires a US national to obtain a license to travel to or support entities in countries of armed conflict, with exceptions for US Government officials. Penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act apply to violations. The Act requires a license for US nationals traveling to or supporting entities in conflict countries, with penalties under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The designation of a Country of Conflict Concern ends when the President certifies that the conditions no longer apply and provides justification to Congress. The President is authorized to issue regulations under this Act, including those under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. Definitions in the Act include "foreign terrorist organization" and "United States national."
